title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
American Airlines said it would trim its schedule of international flights next summer because of Boeing's delays in delivering new 787 Dreamliners.

---

A strong economic recovery and persistent labor shortage pushed jobless claims to their lowest level in more than half a century last week.

---

Company founders and leaders are unloading their stock at historic levels, with some selling shares in their businesses for the first time in years as valuations soar.

---

Starbucks baristas in Buffalo, N.Y., voted to form the first labor union at one of the coffee giant's own U.S. cafes in its 50-year history.

---

SEC chief Gensler took aim at SPACs, saying they provide ordinary investors with incomplete information and insufficient protection against conflicts of interest and fraud.

---

Fitch said Evergrande and a second big Chinese property developer, Kaisa, had defaulted after missing U.S. dollar bond payments.

---

The Nasdaq and S&P 500 fell 1.7% and 0.7%, respectively, as stocks continued to trade fitfully. The Dow ended little changed.

---

Italy's antitrust regulator fined Amazon $1.28 billion, saying it harmed competitors by favoring third-party sellers that use the company's logistics services.

---

Volkswagen CEO Diess has survived a monthslong battle with labor leaders but will now lead the auto maker on a shorter leash.
